body.p: Museums do not only store and display objects from archaeological sites like Nimrud. They are also important centres of research in their own right. These case studies from museums in the UK explore some of the behind-the-scenes investigations being carried out on Nimrud objects in 2013-14. More will be posted during the next phase of the project.

How do museums care for Assyrian artefacts in their collections? In summer 2013 the Nimrud Project visited Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery to see how they look after their collection of 3000-year-old ivory carvings from Nimrud. Conservator Alexandra Cantrill gave us a behind-the-scenes look at the conservation work that helps to preserve these objects for future generations.

esp:h.esp:link: Investigating the materiality of inscriptions at the British Museum

body.p: Academic study of cuneiform inscriptions has traditionally relied on hand-drawn copies of the inscribed text. However, valuable information can be gleaned from studying clay tablets and other inscribed materials as physical objects in their own right. At the British Museum, Assyriologist Dr Jon Taylor examines the evidence left behind on the tablets, to reveal the ways in which ancient scribes wrote their texts, and even to identify individual scribes from their handwriting.
